content: The "Secure Fence Restoration Act of 2015" is also known as the Act. It focuses on fencing along and operational control of the Southwest border. The "Secure Fence Restoration Act of 2015" amends the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996 by setting a deadline for fencing construction by December 31, 2017 and updating the mileage determination to 2017. It also removes subparagraph (D) and amends the Secure Fence Act of 2006 regarding operational control of the Southwest border. The "Secure Fence Restoration Act of 2015" amends the deadline for fencing construction to December 31, 2017 and includes consultation with State and local officials along the US-Mexico border. SEC. 3. PROHIBITION ON ACTIONS THAT IMPEDE BORDER SECURITY ON CERTAIN FEDERAL LAND. The "National Security and Federal Lands Protection Act" prohibits the Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture from impeding U.S. Customs and Border Protection activities within 100 miles of an international land border on Federal land. Customs and Border Protection is authorized immediate access to Federal land for search and rescue operations and to prevent unlawful entries into the United States. The "National Security and Federal Lands Protection Act" allows the Secretary of the Interior or Agriculture to conduct activities within 100 miles of the international land border to prevent unlawful entries into the United States, including construction of roads and barriers, vehicle patrols, and deployment of surveillance equipment. The waiver by the Secretary of Homeland Security on April 1, 2008, under the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996 applies to all Federal land within 100 miles of the international borders for U.S. Customs and Border Protection activities. The Secretary of Homeland Security waived multiple laws for U.S. Customs and Border Protection activities near international borders. The laws include the Wilderness Act, National Environmental Policy Act, Endangered Species Act, and others. The Secretary of Homeland Security waived multiple laws for U.S. Customs and Border Protection activities near international borders, including the Wilderness Act, National Environmental Policy Act, and Endangered Species Act. The waiver does not provide authority to restrict legal uses such as grazing, hunting, mining, or recreational activities on land under the jurisdiction of the Secretary of the Interior or Agriculture. The Act does not affect State or private lands and does not grant authority over them. It also does not override treaties or agreements with Indian tribes.
